desc: EPCAM encodes a transmembrane glycoprotein that functions in cell signaling, migration and proliferation. EPCAM is overexpressed in a diverse range of cancers.

EpCAM (epithelial cell adhesion molecule) is a type I transmembrane glycoprotein which is expressed on normal epithelial cells and has important roles in cell signaling, migration, proliferation and differentiation. It functions as a transmembrane glycoprotein that specifically mediates epithelial specific intercellular cell-adhesion (PMID: 21576002). Germline deletions in the EpCAM gene cause Lynch syndrome via epigenetic silencing of MSH2 (MutS protein homolog 2), leading to a predisposition to colorectal and endometrial cancers (PMID: 19098912). EpCAM is also overexpressed in certain types of solid tumors, though its role in this setting is not fully understood. The bi-specific antibody catumaxomab targets both EpCAM and the T-cell antigen CD3 in an attempt to recruit and activate immune effector cells at the tumor site (PMID: 11588051), and is approved for malignant ascites in patients with EpCAM-positive cancers (PMID: 20473913).
